annotated_bib.problem_stmt: Many members of the populace of the city of Boston, along with the United States and the World, do not have access to the benefits of modern technology.
annotated_bib.citation: Thomas, J., (2013). "Association for Molecular Pathology et al. v. Myriad Genetics et al.." United States Reports. 569. Available: http://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/12pdf/12-398_1b7d.pdf.
annotated_bib.annotation: This judgement, rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States, the highest court in the United States, deals with the patentability of isolated deoxyriboneucleic acid (DNA). Decided by the court, was that isolated DNA was not patentable. It more broadly deals with the patentability of laws of nature, natural phenomena, and abstract ideas(2). This judgement, while not exactly applicable to the problem, could be used as a model argument against such patented technologies that some may view as human rights or fundamental to life.
annotated_bib.citation: United Nations Human Rights Council. (2016, June, 27). "The promotion, protection, and enjoyment of human rights on the Internet." United Nations General Assembly. 32nd Session. Agenda item 3. Available: http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/HRC/32/L.20.
annotated_bib.annotation:
This statement, from the United Nations (UN) Human Rights Council, which deals with the promotion and protection of human rights worldwide, broadly states that access to the internet is a "universal" right.
This declaration, whilst being non-binding, represents the conviction of the UN that access to the Internet is a fundamental human right.
